nodes.text: [Disclaimer: I am writing all this more-or-less as I'm learning about it, so if anyone who knows more than me thinks I'm full of shit please, by all means, let me know]
@ember_ember1 More reporting on the idea locally: https://t.co/uybr9Zq5n1

@ember_ember1 You are right on. I have attended some of the PCCEP mtgs around T&R and will say their will be a plan but not yet. \n\nBut you are right to call out, there has been no regime change. What Ted/PPB likely means is a listening session. Thats not truth or reconciliation

I hadn't actually heard about the Truth and Reconciliation project before now, and admittedly didn't know much about the concept of Truth and Reconciliation Commissions in general.\n\n(1/9) https://t.co/jv4IYvtUtO

Anyway, if you haven't gotten your Recommended Daily Value of out-loud "Fuck Ted Wheeler" in yet, now (as always) is a perfect time.

Fuck Ted Wheeler.

(9/9)

This is, obviously, bullshit. Racism and police abuses are alive and well in Portland, and the suggestion that we need to "reconcile" with those abusers *when they haven't even changed their behavior* is, frankly, insulting.\n\n(8/9)

...but I do think it's significant that framing it as "Truth and Reconciliation" carries the implicit assumption that Portland's (and especially PPB's) racist history is a thing of the past—that we just need to make amends for the past, then all hug it out and move on.\n\n(7/9)

"A truth commission ... is focused on the past, rather than in ongoing events"

Now, I don't claim to be an expert on what Portland is planning (if @JakeDockter is to be believed, there is no plan)...

(6/9)

They've historically been used after major regime changes to investigate human rights abuses under the old regime.

Alright. I want to go back to that first part of the definition, though:

(5/9)

...gathering information on their experiences; (4) is a temporary body, with the aim of concluding with a final report; and (5) is officially authorized or empowered by the state under review.'"\n\n(4/9)

Wikipedia: "According to one widely cited definition: 'A truth commission (1) is focused on the past, rather than in ongoing events; (2) investigates a pattern of events that took place over a period of time; (3) engages directly and broadly with the affected population...\n\n(3/9)

Per @alex_zee's article today, the project "refers to the intention for PPB and the community to work together to confront the city's history of racist policing".

Okay. So what exactly *is* a Truth and Reconciliation Commission, you (read: I) ask?

(2/9)
